Previous Next

netsquid.components.qchannel

Defines a quantum channel, which is essentially a Channel intended for transmitting qubits. It also facilitates qubit noise and loss. Note that transmission is used in the loose sense of moving the qubit through time, not necessarily through space. For example, a quantum memory or quantum gate are also quantum channels because they use the same send and receive functionality, and may wish to specify delay, noise and loss models.

class netsquid.components.qchannel.QuantumChannel(name, delay=0, length=0, models=None, transmit_empty_items=False, properties=None, **kwargs)

Bases: Channel

A one-way quantum channel capable of transmitting qubit(s) with delay, loss and noise.

Functions similarly to Channel but for qubits.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of channel for identification purposes.

  • delay (float, optional) – Fixed transmission delay to use if delay_model is None [ns].

  • length (float, optional) – Length of channel [km]. May be used by delay, loss and noise models.

  • models (dict or None, optional) – Models associated with this component. Will first specify them by their type and them set them. See the Models section to see which (key, Model) pair it recognizes.

  • transmit_empty_items (bool, optional) – Whether to transmit items equal to None. This includes items that become None after input prepocessing. Default is False.

  • properties (dict or None, optional) – Extra properties associated with this component.

Properties:

length (int) – Length of the channel.

Ports:

  • send – Input port for transmitting messages.

  • recv – Output port for receiving messages.

Models:

  • delay_model (DelayModel or None, optional) – Callable object that generates a transmission delay. If None, FixedDelayModel is used. Non-trivial use of this functionality can result in messages arriving out of order.

  • quantum_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel or None, optional) – Callable object intended to probabilistically apply quantum noise to qubit(s) when they are received from the channel. If None, no error model is applied.

  • quantum_loss_model (QuantumErrorModel or None, optional) – Callable object intended to compute whether the qubit(s) are (collectively) lost when they are put on the channel. If None, no error model is applied.

Notes

QChannel supports multiple concurrent transmissions. A FIFO order is guaranteed. Delays generated by a delay_model that do not conform to FIFO will raise an exception.

preprocess_inputs(delay, qubits)

Process sent qubits to see if they will be lost during transmission.

Parameters:

  • delay (float) – Time that qubit(s) will spend transmitting on channel.

  • qubits (list of Qubit) – Qubits being transmitted. Qubits can also be None.

Returns:

Preprocessed qubits being transmitted, with lost qubits either set to``None`` or removed (see ).

Return type:

list of Qubit

Raises:

ValueError – If qubits is not a list of qubits. Qubits can also be None.

postprocess_outputs(delta_time, qubits)

Postprocess outputs as they are taken off the channel.

Parameters:

  • delta_time (float) – Time that qubits spent on the channel.

  • qubits (list of Qubit) – Qubits being transmitted.

Returns:

Postprocessed output items.

Return type:

list of Qubit

add_ports(self, names)

Add ports to this component.

Added ports are accessible via ports.

Parameters:

names (list of str) – Names of ports.

Returns:

List of the ports with the given names.

Return type:

list of Port

Notes

If a port with this name already exists it is also returned in the list, but not overwritten.

add_property(self, name, value=None, mutable=True, value_type=None, value_constraints=None)

Add a property to this component.

Properties can be accessed and modified via the properties attribute.

If a property with this name already exists, an attempt will be made to set the new value.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the property.

  • value (Any) – Value of the property.

  • mutable (bool, optional) – Whether the property is mutable.

  • value_type (type, optional) – Type of this property

  • value_constraints (~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint or list of ~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint , optional) – constraint checks to verify if value is a valid value

add_subcomponent(self, component, name=None, forward_input=None, forward_output=None, add_ports=False)

Add a subcomponent to this component.

Subcomponents can be accessed using the subcomponents property.

If a component already exists with this name identifier it will be replaced.

Parameters:

  • component (Component) – Component to add.

  • name (str or None, optional) – Custom name identifier for component. If None (default), the name of the component being added is used. If a component using the same name already exists it is overridden.

  • forward_input (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward input from parent component to subcomponent. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • forward_output (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward output from subcomponent to parent component. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • add_ports (bool, optional) – If ports should be created if they do not yet exist. Default False

Raises:

ComponentHierarchyError – If the component to be added is already related to this component as a sub or super component at any depth. Or if the component is already a subcomponent of an other component.

Example

Instead of

>>> from netsquid.components import Component
...
>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child)
>>> parent.ports["in_p"].forward_input(child.ports["in_c"])
>>> child.ports["out_c"].forward_output(parent.ports["out_p"])

One can do

>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child,
...     forward_input=[("in_p", "in_c")],
...     forward_output=[("out_p", "out_c")])
compute_delay(self)

Sample a transmission delay.

Returns:

A sample transmission delay to use [ns].

Return type:

float

delay_mean

mean of channel’s delay model.

Type:

float

delay_std

standard deviation of channel’s delay model.

Type:

float

has_subcomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a subcomponent of this component at any level.

Returns:

True if component contained as a subcomponent at any level, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

has_supercomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a supercomponent of this component at any level.

last_rx_time

Simulation time at which the last transmission will be received.

If the last transmission time is in the past (message is waiting) or not applicable (channel is empty), -1 is returned.

Notes

This attribute can be used by a delay model to ensure computed delays abide by first-in-first-out policy.

Type:

float

models

the models associated with this component.

Models that a component can hold are strictly define at construction. To change the model use: models[name_model] = model().

Type:

ConstrainedMap

name

Name of component for identification and display purposes.

Type:

str

output_empty

Whether the receiving end of this channel is currently empty.

Type:

bool

peek(self, int index=0, header=None, bool postprocess=False, **kwargs)

Peek at the item(s) of the next available message of a channel.

The message may still be in transit. Use index to peek at any message being transmitted.

The items(s) will be postprocessed as if they were just put on the channel (delta_time of 0). However, depending on the loss model this may still affect them!

Parameters:

  • index (int, optional) – Index of message to peek, where 0 is the next arriving message.

  • header (Immutable or None, optional) – Header of the message to retrieve. If None, all available items will be retrieved.

  • postprocess (bool) – Whether to postprocess the output e.g. apply noise or decode. A delta_time of 0 is used. Important: this can unintentionally alter the message e.g. a quantum noise model may measure the transmitted qubits.

Returns:

  • list of Any – The item(s) peeked on the channel. If channel is empty at index returned list is empty.

  • bool – Whether peeked item have been received; otherwise they are still transmitting. Meaningless if peeked message is empty.

ports

ports belonging to this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

properties

the properties associated with this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

receive(self, header=None, **kwargs)

Retrieves received item(s), e.g. qubits or classical data, on the channel output.

An item can only be retrieved once. A header can be used to retrieve selected items (see put), otherwise all available item(s) are retrieved.

Parameters:

header (Immutable or None, optional) – Header of the items to retrieve. If None, all available items will be retrieved.

Returns:

  • list of Any – The item(s) retrieved from the channel. If channel output is empty an empty list is returned.

  • float – The time the item spent on the channel. If the channel output is empty then 0 is returned [ns].

Notes

Item(s) can be retrieved when the current time instant matches their arrival time. Because events scheduled at the same time instant may occur in a random order, it is possible for items(s) to be retrieved before their ready event occurs. In this case the ready event still occurs but the output will be empty.

If receive is called without a header for a message with headers, then the items are returned per header in the order the headers were first put. For instance, for the sequence of (header, item) puts: (‘A’, 1), (‘B’, 2), (‘C’, 3), (‘A’, 4), a receive with no header would return [1, 4, 2, 3].

rem_subcomponent(self, name)

Remove a subcomponent from this component.

Outgoing port connections are disconnected to keep the hierarchy consistent; That means that any port connections to the parent or siblings are disconnected. Input ports to subcomponents remain.

Parameters:

name (str) – Name identifier for component.

remove(self)

Removes the entity from the simulation.

reset(self)

Reset the channel.

Empties any items on channel output and cancels any transmissions in progress.

send(self, items, append=True, header=None, **kwargs)

Put item(s) to be sent, e.g. qubits or a classical data, onto the channel.

Parameters:

  • items (Any or list of Any) – Any item or list of items e.g. a classical or quantum message. Note that a tuple is treated as a single item.

  • header (Immutable or None, optional) – The header to use for message wrapping these items. This header can be used to select just the currently sent items upon receive. If None no header is used.

Notes

It is possible for item(s) to be retrieved before their ready event occurs (see receive()).

Only one ready event is ever scheduled.

specify_model(self, name, model_type=None)

Specify the model types needed by this component.

Models that are not first specified cannot be set. To set a model do Component.models[name_model] = model.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Key of item.

  • model_type (~netsquid.components.models.Model) – Type of model. If None, ~netsquid.components.models.Model base class is set.

Raises:

KeyError – If a model with name has already been specified.

subcomponents

Return list of subcomponents of this component and their identifiers.

Returns:

Subcomponents of this component.

Return type:

ConstrainedMap

supercomponent

parent component, if any.

Type:

Component or None

transmit_empty_items

Whether to transmit items equal to None. This includes items that become None after input prepocessing. Default is False.

Type:

bool

transmitting

Whether this channel is transmitting item(s).

Type:

bool

uid

returns a unique identifier for this entity in the simulation.

Each entity has a unique identifier in the simulation.

Type:

int
